#Text=eday laws.
#Text=Mr.

#Text=Hume presented s petition from some operatives at Manchester, complaining of the Corn leiws, as injurious to their interest, as rendering their wages inadequate to their support, and praying generally for relief.
#Text=•Mr.
#Text=Wells denied that the present distress arose from the operation of the Corn Laws.
#Text=Mr.
#Text=I).
#Text=W. lIAttVF.y entered his protest against any suclt doctrine as that of the hon. member for Maidstone.
#Text=If the Corn Laws did not lend to raise the price of bread, ami keep up high prices to the landlords, why, he asked, were they continued ?
#Text=The high price of bread greatly aggravated the public distress, and the repeal of the Corn Laws would materially tend to diminish it.
#Text=Mr.
#Text=W.
#Text=Whitmore said that he was no advocate for the Corn Laws, but he would not attribute the present high prices to the operation of the law as it now existed.
#Text=He rather thought the scarcity of the harvest had produced it.

#Text=He did not believe that the present distress arose from the system of free trade ; for while the silk weavers were out of employment, so were the cotton weavers, and nothing new could be said as to the importation of cotton.
#Text=Mr.
#Text=H.

#Text=Thompson- said the present distress arose from the fact of shutting our ports against foreign corn for a series of years, and prohibiting the foreigner from growing a steady supply for this market.
#Text=It was not the tax of last year which produced the distress now existing, but the operation of the prohibitory laws which had been for years fn existence.
#Text=He hoped this house would be crowded with petiiinns for a repeal of those obnoxious laws.
#Text=Mr.
#Text=M.
#Text=Fitzgerald complained S( the system of striking the averages, and hoped some reiurdy would be applied to it, as the returns now made had a manifest tendency to deceive the people.
#Text=Air.
#Text=Secretarr Peel said, if a better system was rendered necessary it win) 111 he attended to by his Majesty** ministers.
#Text=Air, Home said that the corn monoply was now starving the people, and should be abolished as soon as possible—Ordered to be printed.
